note: Acetaminophen <1g/day for short course has minimal effect on INR
Acetaminophen <2g/day for one week has minimal warfarin interaction
Acetaminophen ~2-3g/day for 2 weeks: moderate INR increase expected
Chronic high-dose acetaminophen (>3g/day) significantly increases INR and bleeding risk
Simvastatin 10mg with amiodarone: manageable with monitoring
Simvastatin 20mg is the FDA max dose with amiodarone; borderline
Simvastatin 40mg with amiodarone: high risk of rhabdomyolysis
Simvastatin 80mg with amiodarone: contraindicated per FDA labeling
Low-dose weekly MTX (7.5-15mg/week) with ibuprofen: moderate risk, monitor renal function
High-dose MTX with ibuprofen: severe risk of MTX toxicity from reduced renal clearance
Low-dose weekly MTX (7.5-15mg/week) with naproxen: moderate risk, monitor renal function
High-dose MTX with naproxen: severe risk of MTX toxicity from reduced renal clearance
Low-dose weekly MTX (7.5-15mg/week) with diclofenac: moderate risk, monitor renal function
High-dose MTX with diclofenac: severe risk of MTX toxicity from reduced renal clearance

High-dose MTX with indomethacin: severe risk of MTX toxicity from reduced renal clearance
Low-dose weekly MTX (7.5-15mg/week) with meloxicam: moderate risk, monitor renal function
High-dose MTX with meloxicam: severe risk of MTX toxicity from reduced renal clearance
Low-dose digoxin (0.0625-0.125mg) with amiodarone: manageable with monitoring and dose reduction
Standard digoxin dose with amiodarone: severe risk of digoxin toxicity; reduce dig dose 50%
Full-dose digoxin with amiodarone: near-certain toxicity, effectively contraindicated
Short-course low-dose ibuprofen: moderate lithium level increase expected, monitor levels
Chronic full-dose ibuprofen: significant lithium accumulation risk, can cause toxicity
Short-course low-dose naproxen: moderate lithium level increase expected, monitor levels
Chronic full-dose naproxen: significant lithium accumulation risk, can cause toxicity
Short-course low-dose diclofenac: moderate lithium level increase expected, monitor levels
Chronic full-dose diclofenac: significant lithium accumulation risk, can cause toxicity
Short-course low-dose indomethacin: moderate lithium level increase expected, monitor levels
Chronic full-dose indomethacin: significant lithium accumulation risk, can cause toxicity
Short-course low-dose celecoxib: moderate lithium level increase expected, monitor levels
Chronic full-dose celecoxib: significant lithium accumulation risk, can cause toxicity
Low-dose ciprofloxacin (250mg): moderate CYP1A2 inhibition, theophylline levels rise 15-20%
High-dose ciprofloxacin (750mg): strong CYP1A2 inhibition, theophylline levels may double
Low-dose colchicine (0.3mg BID) with clarithromycin: reduced dose mitigates CYP3A4/P-gp interaction
Full-dose colchicine with clarithromycin: fatal colchicine toxicity reported
Low-dose atorvastatin with gemfibrozil: reduced myopathy risk, still requires CK monitoring
High-dose atorvastatin with gemfibrozil: significant rhabdomyolysis risk
Low-dose rosuvastatin with gemfibrozil: reduced myopathy risk, still requires CK monitoring
High-dose rosuvastatin with gemfibrozil: significant rhabdomyolysis risk

High-dose simvastatin with gemfibrozil: significant rhabdomyolysis risk
Low-dose lovastatin with gemfibrozil: reduced myopathy risk, still requires CK monitoring
High-dose lovastatin with gemfibrozil: significant rhabdomyolysis risk
Short low-dose NSAID with cyclosporine: moderate nephrotoxicity risk, monitor creatinine
Chronic full-dose diclofenac with cyclosporine: synergistic nephrotoxicity
Low-dose valproic acid: modest displacement of phenytoin from protein binding
High-dose valproic acid: significant phenytoin displacement + CYP2C9 inhibition
Short low-dose prednisone burst: minimal INR effect
Chronic high-dose prednisone: significant INR increase + GI bleeding risk additive with warfarin
Short low-dose prednisolone burst: minimal INR effect
Chronic high-dose prednisolone: significant INR increase + GI bleeding risk additive with warfarin

Chronic high-dose methylprednisolone: significant INR increase + GI bleeding risk additive with warfarin
Short low-dose dexamethasone burst: minimal INR effect
Chronic high-dose dexamethasone: significant INR increase + GI bleeding risk additive with warfarin

Minimal doses of morphine + lorazepam: respiratory depression risk present but lower at minimal doses
Minimal doses of morphine + diazepam: respiratory depression risk present but lower at minimal doses

Minimal doses of hydrocodone + lorazepam: respiratory depression risk present but lower at minimal doses

Minimal doses of fentanyl + lorazepam: respiratory depression risk present but lower at minimal doses
Minimal doses of fentanyl + diazepam: respiratory depression risk present but lower at minimal doses
Low-dose spironolactone (12.5-25mg) with lisinopril in normal renal function: manageable hyperkalemia risk
Low-dose spironolactone (12.5-25mg) with enalapril in normal renal function: manageable hyperkalemia risk
Low-dose spironolactone (12.5-25mg) with ramipril in normal renal function: manageable hyperkalemia risk
Low-dose spironolactone (12.5-25mg) with captopril in normal renal function: manageable hyperkalemia risk

Fluconazole 400mg with tacrolimus: strong CYP3A4 inhibition, severe toxicity risk

IV ciprofloxacin + oral omeprazole: no absorption interaction when cipro is IV

IV ciprofloxacin + oral famotidine: no absorption interaction when cipro is IV

IV ciprofloxacin + oral sucralfate: no absorption interaction when cipro is IV

IV levofloxacin bypasses absorption interaction with omeprazole
Oral levofloxacin + oral sucralfate: chelation reduces absorption
IV levofloxacin bypasses absorption interaction with sucralfate
Oral tacrolimus + oral fluconazole: full CYP3A4 inhibition + first-pass effect amplification
IV tacrolimus + fluconazole: systemic CYP3A4 inhibition still relevant but no first-pass amplification
Oral tacrolimus + oral itraconazole: full CYP3A4 inhibition + first-pass effect amplification
IV tacrolimus + itraconazole: systemic CYP3A4 inhibition still relevant but no first-pass amplification

IV tacrolimus + posaconazole: systemic CYP3A4 inhibition still relevant but no first-pass amplification

Oral budesonide + ketoconazole: CYP3A4 inhibition increases budesonide AUC 6-8x

Topical fluticasone + ritonavir: negligible systemic absorption from topical route

IV midazolam + ketoconazole: AUC increase 3-5x (no first-pass), still severe but manageable in monitored setting

Oral nitrate + PDE5 inhibitor: contraindicated regardless of route
Even topical nitroglycerin with sildenafil: still contraindicated, sufficient systemic absorption
Oral erythromycin + simvastatin: strong intestinal + hepatic CYP3A4 inhibition
IV erythromycin: still inhibits hepatic CYP3A4 but less intestinal first-pass effect

IV doxycycline: no absorption interaction possible
Oral tetracycline chelation with sucralfate aluminum
IV tetracycline bypasses chelation interaction

ciprofloxacin taken 2h before omeprazole: most absorption complete, reduced interaction
ciprofloxacin taken 4h before omeprazole: negligible interaction with adequate separation
Simultaneous ciprofloxacin + famotidine: maximal chelation/absorption interference
ciprofloxacin taken 2h before famotidine: most absorption complete, reduced interaction
ciprofloxacin taken 4h before famotidine: negligible interaction with adequate separation

levofloxacin taken 2h before omeprazole: most absorption complete, reduced interaction

Simultaneous levofloxacin + famotidine: maximal chelation/absorption interference
levofloxacin taken 2h before famotidine: most absorption complete, reduced interaction
levofloxacin taken 4h before famotidine: negligible interaction with adequate separation
Simultaneous levofloxacin + sucralfate: maximal chelation/absorption interference
levofloxacin taken 2h before sucralfate: most absorption complete, reduced interaction
levofloxacin taken 4h before sucralfate: negligible interaction with adequate separation

Levothyroxine taken 4h before omeprazole: adequate separation minimizes interaction
Simultaneous levothyroxine + cholestyramine: reduced T4 absorption
Levothyroxine taken 4h before cholestyramine: adequate separation minimizes interaction
Simultaneous levothyroxine + sucralfate: reduced T4 absorption
Levothyroxine taken 4h before sucralfate: adequate separation minimizes interaction
Simultaneous: cholestyramine binds warfarin in GI tract, reduces absorption
Warfarin 2h before cholestyramine: most warfarin absorbed, minimal binding interaction
Simultaneous: some chelation possible with divalent cations in formulation
2h separation: adequate to prevent any interaction
Simultaneous: maximal inhibition of MTX renal tubular secretion
MTX given well before probenecid: some MTX already cleared renally before probenecid effect
Simultaneous: cholestyramine binds mycophenolic acid, interrupting enterohepatic recycling
4h separation: reduced binding of mycophenolate metabolites in gut
Simultaneous: cholestyramine binds digoxin reducing absorption and enterohepatic recycling
Digoxin 2h before cholestyramine: most digoxin absorbed before binding occurs
Normal renal function (GFR>60): metformin clearance adequate, low lactic acidosis risk
Impaired renal function (GFR 30-45): gentamicin nephrotoxicity + metformin accumulation = lactic acidosis risk
Severe renal impairment (GFR<30): metformin contraindicated; adding nephrotoxin is extremely dangerous
lisinopril + spironolactone with normal renal function: hyperkalemia risk manageable with monitoring
lisinopril + spironolactone with poor renal function: life-threatening hyperkalemia very likely
enalapril + spironolactone with normal renal function: hyperkalemia risk manageable with monitoring
enalapril + spironolactone with poor renal function: life-threatening hyperkalemia very likely

ramipril + spironolactone with poor renal function: life-threatening hyperkalemia very likely

benazepril + spironolactone with poor renal function: life-threatening hyperkalemia very likely
captopril + spironolactone with normal renal function: hyperkalemia risk manageable with monitoring
captopril + spironolactone with poor renal function: life-threatening hyperkalemia very likely
Younger adult on warfarin + aspirin: bleeding risk present but lower baseline risk
Elderly patient on warfarin + aspirin: high bleeding risk, falls risk multiplicative
Younger adult on warfarin + clopidogrel: bleeding risk present but lower baseline risk
Elderly patient on warfarin + clopidogrel: high bleeding risk, falls risk multiplicative
Younger adult on warfarin + naproxen: bleeding risk present but lower baseline risk
Elderly patient on warfarin + naproxen: high bleeding risk, falls risk multiplicative
Younger adult on warfarin + ibuprofen: bleeding risk present but lower baseline risk
Elderly patient on warfarin + ibuprofen: high bleeding risk, falls risk multiplicative
dabigatran + amiodarone with normal renal function: P-gp inhibition increases dabigatran levels moderately
dabigatran + amiodarone with renal impairment: reduced clearance + P-gp inhibition = high bleeding risk
rivaroxaban + amiodarone with normal renal function: P-gp inhibition increases rivaroxaban levels moderately
rivaroxaban + amiodarone with renal impairment: reduced clearance + P-gp inhibition = high bleeding risk
apixaban + amiodarone with normal renal function: P-gp inhibition increases apixaban levels moderately
apixaban + amiodarone with renal impairment: reduced clearance + P-gp inhibition = high bleeding risk
edoxaban + amiodarone with normal renal function: P-gp inhibition increases edoxaban levels moderately
edoxaban + amiodarone with renal impairment: reduced clearance + P-gp inhibition = high bleeding risk
Normal hepatic function: CYP2D6 inhibition of metoprolol: hepatic impairment amplifies first-pass effect changes
Moderate hepatic impairment (Child-Pugh B): CYP2D6 inhibition of metoprolol: hepatic impairment amplifies first-pass effect changes
Normal hepatic function: CYP3A4 inhibition: hepatic impairment reduces midazolam clearance further
Moderate hepatic impairment (Child-Pugh B): CYP3A4 inhibition: hepatic impairment reduces midazolam clearance further
Normal hepatic function: CYP3A4 interaction: hepatic impairment increases statin exposure and myopathy risk
Moderate hepatic impairment (Child-Pugh B): CYP3A4 interaction: hepatic impairment increases statin exposure and myopathy risk
Normal hepatic function: CYP2C9 inhibition of losartan activation: hepatic impairment affects prodrug conversion
Moderate hepatic impairment (Child-Pugh B): CYP2C9 inhibition of losartan activation: hepatic impairment affects prodrug conversion
Pregnancy: warfarin already high-risk, any interaction partner increases fetal/maternal bleeding risk
Pregnancy: methotrexate is teratogenic, NSAIDs also contraindicated in 3rd trimester; combination absolutely contraindicated
Pregnancy: valproic acid is teratogenic; interaction with lamotrigine (levels increase) adds seizure instability risk
Pediatric: codeine contraindicated in children <12; combination with promethazine has caused deaths
Pediatric: children more susceptible to extrapyramidal effects from dopamine antagonist combination
Pediatric: serotonin syndrome risk higher in children; tramadol seizure risk also elevated
CYP2D6 poor metabolizer: codeine cannot convert to morphine; fluoxetine CYP2D6 inhibition is redundant
CYP2D6 poor metabolizer: tramadol already poorly activated; paroxetine inhibition less clinically relevant
Elderly polypharmacy patient: multiple CYP inhibitors + warfarin + amiodarone = extreme bleeding/toxicity risk
Elderly with renal impairment on polypharmacy: digoxin + verapamil risk of fatal bradycardia/AV block
Low body weight + reduced renal function: both drugs have narrow therapeutic index, additive nephrotoxicity severe
Normal weight + good renal function: additive nephrotoxicity manageable with monitoring
Normal renal function: NSAIDs reduce lithium clearance but kidneys have reserve capacity
Poor renal function: lithium already at risk of accumulation, NSAIDs will push to toxic levels
Normal renal function: clarithromycin increases digoxin levels via P-gp, but renal clearance partially compensates
Elderly with renal impairment: digoxin toxicity nearly certain with clarithromycin P-gp inhibition
Normal renal function: furosemide may mildly affect metformin clearance, clinically insignificant
Renal impairment: reduced metformin clearance + diuretic-induced volume depletion = lactic acidosis risk
Normal renal function: allopurinol inhibits xanthine oxidase, azathioprine metabolite 6-MP accumulates regardless
Renal impairment: further reduced clearance of 6-MP metabolites, life-threatening myelosuppression
Elderly with hepatic compromise: fluvoxamine CYP1A2 inhibition causes dangerous clozapine accumulation
Young adult, normal liver: fluvoxamine still strongly inhibits CYP1A2 but clearance capacity is better
Low-dose carbamazepine: less CYP3A4/UGT induction, lamotrigine levels moderately reduced
Full-dose carbamazepine: maximal enzyme induction, lamotrigine levels reduced 40-50%
Even low-dose rifampin is a potent CYP inducer; warfarin effect dramatically reduced
Full-dose rifampin: warfarin essentially ineffective, massive CYP2C9/3A4 induction
Low-dose quetiapine (25-50mg) with ketoconazole: CYP3A4 inhibition manageable at reduced quetiapine dose
Full-dose quetiapine with ketoconazole: quetiapine AUC increase 6x, sedation/QT risk
Clopidogrel loading dose (300-600mg) + omeprazole: CYP2C19 inhibition most critical during loading when rapid activation needed
Oral metronidazole + warfarin: full CYP2C9 inhibition via first-pass + systemic
IV metronidazole: systemic CYP2C9 inhibition still present but no intestinal first-pass amplification
IV vancomycin + IV gentamicin: additive nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity at full systemic exposure
Oral vancomycin (for C. diff): negligible systemic absorption, nephrotoxicity interaction minimal
Oral nystatin: not systemically absorbed, no interaction with cyclosporine
Topical nystatin: no systemic absorption, no interaction
Oral clindamycin + oral erythromycin: macrolide-lincosamide antagonism at ribosomal binding site
Topical clindamycin: minimal systemic absorption, no meaningful antagonism with systemic erythromycin
Oral diltiazem: intestinal + hepatic CYP3A4 inhibition increases simvastatin exposure 4-5x
IV diltiazem: primarily hepatic CYP3A4 inhibition, less intestinal first-pass amplification for simvastatin
Inhaled albuterol + oral propranolol: beta-blocker antagonizes bronchodilation even with inhaled route
Oral albuterol + propranolol: systemic beta-agonist/antagonist competition, bronchospasm + hypertensive crisis risk
Inhaled ipratropium: minimal systemic anticholinergic effect, low antagonism of cholinesterase inhibitor
IV fentanyl + ketoconazole: CYP3A4 inhibition reduces fentanyl clearance regardless of route
Simultaneous: colesevelam binds warfarin in GI tract reducing absorption
Warfarin 4h before colesevelam: complete absorption before binding agent present
Simultaneous: colestipol binds warfarin in GI tract reducing absorption
Warfarin 4h before colestipol: complete absorption before binding agent present
Simultaneous: cholestyramine binds levothyroxine, can reduce absorption by 90%
Levothyroxine 4h before cholestyramine: adequate separation for T4 absorption
Simultaneous: metoclopramide increases GI motility, reduces digoxin absorption time
Digoxin 2h before metoclopramide: digoxin largely absorbed before motility change
Simultaneous: some divalent cation chelation possible
2h separation eliminates any absorption interaction
Simultaneous: antacids can reduce gabapentin absorption by ~20%
Gabapentin 2h before antacid: absorption essentially complete
Simultaneous: sucralfate binds phenytoin in GI tract
phenytoin 2h before sucralfate: adequate separation prevents binding
Simultaneous: sucralfate binds digoxin in GI tract
digoxin 2h before sucralfate: adequate separation prevents binding

Elderly: oxycodone + benzodiazepine respiratory depression risk markedly increased; falls risk additive
Elderly: hydrocodone + benzodiazepine respiratory depression risk markedly increased; falls risk additive
Elderly: fentanyl + benzodiazepine respiratory depression risk markedly increased; falls risk additive
Elderly: hydromorphone + benzodiazepine respiratory depression risk markedly increased; falls risk additive
Elderly: serotonergic interaction + increased QT sensitivity with age
Elderly: ciprofloxacin + amiodarone QT prolongation risk higher with age-related cardiac conduction changes

Elderly: levofloxacin + amiodarone QT prolongation risk higher with age-related cardiac conduction changes
Younger adult: levofloxacin + amiodarone QT prolongation risk still severe but baseline cardiac risk lower
Elderly: moxifloxacin + amiodarone QT prolongation risk higher with age-related cardiac conduction changes

Hepatic impairment: phenytoin metabolism already reduced; adding CYP2C9 inhibitor causes toxicity
Pregnancy: ACE inhibitors teratogenic (2nd/3rd trimester); spironolactone anti-androgenic; both contraindicated
Multiple highly protein-bound drugs: warfarin + phenytoin displacement competition amplified by other bound drugs
Normal renal function: TMP-SMX + tacrolimus: hyperkalemia + nephrotoxicity risk manageable
Renal impairment: TMP blocks K+ secretion + tacrolimus nephrotoxic = severe hyperkalemia risk
Normal renal function: cyclosporine + ACEi hyperkalemia risk present, monitor K+
Renal impairment: cyclosporine nephrotoxicity + ACEi reduced K+ excretion = dangerous hyperkalemia
Elderly: reduced theophylline clearance baseline + CYP1A2 inhibition by erythromycin = toxicity
Oral verapamil: intestinal + hepatic CYP3A4/P-gp inhibition maximally increases simvastatin exposure
IV verapamil: hepatic CYP3A4 inhibition present but no intestinal first-pass amplification of simvastatin
Very low single-dose colchicine (0.3mg) with ritonavir: still dangerous but may be used for acute gout per FDA guidance
Repeat-dose colchicine with ritonavir: contraindicated, fatal colchicine toxicity from massive CYP3A4/P-gp inhibition
Simultaneous: colestipol binds levothyroxine reducing absorption significantly
Levothyroxine 4h before colestipol: adequate separation for thyroid hormone absorption
Normal renal: cyclosporine increases everolimus levels + additive nephrotoxicity; requires TDM
Renal impairment: dual immunosuppressant nephrotoxicity with impaired clearance = organ-threatening
Even lowest sildenafil dose with nitrates: contraindicated due to severe hypotension risk
Low-dose methadone + fluconazole: CYP3A4 inhibition increases methadone levels but from low baseline
High-dose methadone + fluconazole: QT prolongation risk + respiratory depression from elevated levels
